stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on broad bug-fixing and visual/gameplay polish while building out an oil-rig interior sub-area in Course 11. He prototypes an entrance slide, creates new hydraulic/piston moving platforms with adjustable speed/pause parameters, wrestles with N64 texture memory limits (including a highly nonstandard texture resolution), fixes culling/update-order bugs, and discusses future plans: open-sourcing the project/engine, a separate Unreal Engine demo leading into a Kickstarter for a new game, and potentially licensing RTYI’s music for an album release.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains multiple documentary-relevant topics: production discipline (self-imposed deadlines), clear design philosophy statements (difficulty curve, anti-“time eraser” modern design), concrete engine/tech constraints (texture memory, culling, update order, 30 FPS threading plan), and future-facing business plans (Unreal demo + Kickstarter, music licensing/album idea).

findings.summary: Kaze is in a “stabilization” phase: going through many previously built levels to fix accumulated bugs with the explicit goal of being able to beta test every level.

He has started setting daily/short-horizon deadlines for himself; after 14 days he reports hitting every deadline, using them to structure work like bug-fixing plus blocking out the ‘OBB underground’.

A ‘Chompy’ enemy/NPC received new action states (rarely triggered, ~1/16 chance) and an updated higher-definition model; Kaze considers making a short standalone video just showcasing how “cute” it is.

RTYI’s warp objects have been extended with two additional parameters beyond stock SM64: warp-object height/hitbox sizing and the camera angle applied when exiting the warp; missing parameters can break behavior (e.g., “for a warp” cases).

N64 texture memory constraints (Fast64 showing 4096/4096 bytes) force aggressive texture planning; Kaze explores combining textures, reducing resolution, and ends up using a highly unusual 96x42 texture to fit a specific sail/edge effect within memory.
findings.quote: I might have to N64 verify this, just to make sure. But this should be fine. Ah yes, my 96 by 42 texture.

findings.summary: Course 11’s oil-rig interior is being made more visually ‘alive’ with moving machinery; Kaze decides to replace multiple static platforms with hydraulic/piston platforms mainly because it looks cooler and improves platforming/climb readability.

He implements a piston platform behavior with variable speed and pause controlled by behavior parameters (B-params), intentionally desynchronizing motion so the machinery doesn’t move in a uniform rhythm.
He fixes a piston platform culling bug by ‘cheaping out’ with a large static culling radius rather than recomputing bounds every tick, prioritizing performance and simplicity over per-frame accuracy.
A platform update-order bug (object order) is addressed by changing spawn/update sequencing (using a spawner) so the platform state updates in the intended order without an extra frame of delay.

Kaze notes an unresolved performance investigation: speedrunners report 30 FPS mode lag. His tentative plan is to restructure threading so in 30 FPS mode the gameplay and rendering threads are merged (rendering moved into gameplay or vice versa) to improve performance.

Door/animation issues are blocked on Lilaa’s quaternion animation exporter; Kaze indicates current door animation work would be a temporary patch that must be redone once quaternion exports are available.
Kaze outlines a post-RTYI plan: build a separate Unreal Engine demo for an unrelated new platformer game, then launch a Kickstarter around the time RTYI releases to fund the new project.
He wants to open-source RTYI’s code (public source) but doubts anyone will produce a true PC port due to the skill/time required (unless it’s just an emulator bundle).

Kaze frames his level difficulty approach as ‘coolness-first’: he doesn’t raise difficulty for its own sake; instead, he moves harder “cool jumps” to later levels and keeps earlier levels’ ‘cool jump threshold’ lower, producing an organic difficulty curve.

Course 11 (Oily Boily Bay/oil-rig area) still needs content polish: picking a unique Yoshi-coin color distinct from other courses, writing/adding correct NPC text (Koopa), ensuring the soap-bar challenge isn’t tedious (adjusting cleanup radius), adding an oil puddle enemy inspired by 3D World’s blob enemies, and finalizing a convincing ‘boiling tar/oil’ surface effect (reflective dark liquid + bubbles/smoke).

biobak.summary: Biobak provides art/asset iteration in real time (e.g., sending Blender files/textures such as the sail), and gives feedback on whether Kaze’s extreme texture-resolution workaround is acceptable.

Biobak is part of the texture/memory tradeoff discussion (texture formats like I4, combining textures, scaling down from 128x64), influencing Kaze’s final decision to fit within N64 texture memory limits.

zeina.summary: Zeina is mentioned as remembering an older ‘lost’ mod (“Hot Tub Mario”), used as a brief example of shared memory/creative history between them.

findings.summary: Lilaa is responsible for a quaternion animation exporter that the project depends on to properly fix door/animation issues; her week-long absence triggered repeated jokes about her being ‘dead,’ highlighting how central her tool is to unblocking animation fixes.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Modern game design is made for people that are depressed and just want to erase time, not for people that want to go have an experience.
memorable_quotes.context: He contrasts his design intent with TikTok/‘time deletion’ habits and modern ‘pick up for 3 minutes’ design trends.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The game boots you directly into the file select. The game doesn’t waste your time. That is important to me.
memorable_quotes.context: He explains a player-respect principle shaping RTYI’s startup flow and menus.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I actually have a really good method for making a good difficulty curve. And that is that I don’t try to make the levels more difficult. I just put the threshold of how cool a jump has to be for it to be worth the difficulty lower.
memorable_quotes.context: He describes his core level-design heuristic: difficulty in service of ‘cool’ movement, not challenge for its own sake.

key_stories.title: From scattered bugs to beta readiness via self-imposed deadlines
key_stories.summary: Kaze describes shifting into a disciplined production mode: daily deadlines and a project-wide bug-fix sweep across levels to prepare for full-level beta testing. He frames today’s work as part of a larger stabilization pass rather than new feature exploration.
key_stories.challenge: Accumulated bugs across many courses and the need to reach a state where every level can be reliably beta tested.
key_stories.process: He sets recurring deadlines (14 days so far), works through levels sequentially, and pairs bug fixing with new blockouts (e.g., OBB underground).
key_stories.outcome: He reports meeting every deadline so far and continuing with a dedicated bug-fix stream as part of the push to a testable build.

key_stories.title: Building hydraulic piston platforms under strict N64 constraints
key_stories.summary: While polishing the oil-rig interior, Kaze decides the area needs more moving machinery. He creates a piston/hydraulic platform behavior with variable speed/pause controlled by behavior parameters and works through multiple engine issues (culling, update order) to make it stable.
key_stories.challenge: Make the area feel like an active machine space and improve platforming without introducing performance/visual glitches.
key_stories.process: He prototypes piston motion with desynced rhythms, tunes B-params, expands a static culling radius to stop pop-in, and adjusts spawn/update sequencing to fix platform ordering.
key_stories.outcome: The pistons work and meaningfully improve the area’s vibe; remaining work is mostly visual polish and integration.

key_stories.title: The cursed texture resolution workaround (96x42)
key_stories.summary: Kaze hits the N64’s texture memory ceiling while trying to preserve a sail’s edge detail. Rather than abandoning the look, he iterates through divisors/packing options and lands on an unusual 96x42 texture size that should fit within 4096 bytes, pending hardware verification.
key_stories.challenge: Preserve a specific visual effect on a texture while staying within strict N64 texture memory limits.
key_stories.process: He tests texture-format constraints, considers combining textures, calculates divisors of 4096/8192, and chooses an unconventional resolution that fits the budget.
key_stories.outcome: A workable texture plan is found, though he flags the need to verify behavior on real N64 constraints.

key_stories.title: Lilaa ‘died’ (for a week): tool dependency becomes a running gag
key_stories.summary: Lilaa’s absence prompts the stream to joke that she died, escalating into a mock funeral and repeated ‘R.I.P.’ comments. Underneath the joke is a real dependency: door/animation fixes are waiting on her quaternion animation exporter.
key_stories.challenge: Animation/door problems remain partially unsolved because the proper pipeline tool (quaternion exporter) isn’t available yet.
key_stories.process: Kaze explains that any interim door fix would be temporary and need rework later; when Lilaa returns in chat, the group resolves the misunderstanding as her simply being away.
key_stories.outcome: Lilaa confirms she saw the ‘RIP’ post; the incident highlights the project’s reliance on specialized community tooling.

key_stories.title: Post-RTYI funding plan: Unreal demo + Kickstarter
key_stories.summary: Kaze lays out a plan to start a separate Unreal Engine project: make a small demo for a new platformer, then time a Kickstarter launch alongside RTYI’s release. He positions this as a path to ‘make big money’ and gain creative freedom for future work.
key_stories.challenge: Long-term sustainability and funding for larger original projects beyond the ROM hack.
key_stories.process: Plan to ship RTYI, develop an Unreal demo in parallel, then use the RTYI release moment to drive attention into a Kickstarter campaign.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete post-release roadmap emerges, implying RTYI is also a stepping stone to an original commercial endeavor.

open_questions.context: Kaze says he is fixing bugs across all levels so that they can beta test every single level.
questions: What does ‘beta test’ mean for RTYI specifically (internal only, trusted community, public)?
What’s the checklist for calling a course beta-ready (no crashes, star logic complete, performance targets, camera rules, collectibles)?
How do you track and triage bugs across 15 courses—issue tracker, Discord threads, personal notes?

open_questions.context: He mentions a deadline combining bug fixes with a blockout for the ‘OBB underground,’ and says they’re almost ready for Course 12.
questions: What is ‘OBB underground’ in the game’s structure (Course 11 sub-area or a separate course)?
What work remains before Course 12 is ready—layout, scripting, art pass, music, or engine support?
How do you decide when to stop polishing an area and move on to the next course?

open_questions.topic: Extended warp parameters and camera rules
open_questions.context: RTYI warps have extra parameters for warp height/hitbox and exit camera angle.
questions: Why were these additional warp parameters necessary—what design problems did stock SM64 warps cause?
How widely are these used across levels (special camera reveals, vertical transitions, anti-softlock design)?
Did adding parameters create compatibility issues with existing tools or level editors?

open_questions.topic: 30 FPS mode lag investigation and threading restructure
open_questions.context: Kaze references speedrunners reporting 30 FPS mode lag and proposes merging gameplay and rendering threads to improve performance in that mode.
questions: What is the current threading model (what runs on which thread) and what changes in 30 FPS mode?
What evidence do you have for the cause of the lag (profiling, frame pacing, synchronization points)?
How risky is the proposed merge—could it introduce desync, input latency, or rendering artifacts?

open_questions.context: Door/animation fixes are waiting on Lilaa’s quaternion animation exporter; Kaze implies current solutions are temporary until the exporter exists.
questions: What exactly breaks without quaternion export—door rotations, skeletal animation, interpolation, precision?
How did this dependency arise (tooling limitation, engine change, custom animation system)?
What is the current state of Lilaa’s exporter and what would it take to finish/integrate it?

open_questions.topic: Course 11 ‘oil’ gameplay loop and enemy design
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions an oil puddle enemy inspired by Mario 3D World and a soap-bar cleaning challenge; he also ensures the sub/objects respawn correctly.
questions: What is the intended player fantasy for this course (cleanup/refinery/industrial platforming), and how do the soap and oil hazards support it?
How will the oil puddle enemy behave (movement, damage, interactions with soap/oil surfaces)?
How do you prevent the cleaning mechanic from becoming tedious while keeping it readable and satisfying?

open_questions.topic: Visual solution for boiling tar/oil on N64
open_questions.context: He struggles to find a reference for boiling oil/tar and lands on a plan: reflective dark liquid with bubbles and smoke, possibly using vertex animation.
questions: What final technique will you use: vertex animation, texture scrolling, particle sprites, or a hybrid?
How do you balance ‘looks good’ against N64-era fillrate/overdraw and texture memory constraints?
Will the boiling effect have gameplay feedback (damage timing, bounce behavior, sound cues)?

open_questions.topic: Open-source release strategy and engine reuse by other hackers
open_questions.context: Kaze intends to make the source public and expects other hacks may adopt the RTYI engine, though he doubts a PC port will happen.
questions: When do you plan to open-source (at release, after, staged releases), and under what license?
What parts will be included/excluded (assets, build scripts, tools, documentation)?
How do you feel about other hacks using your engine—what guardrails or support do you want to provide?

open_questions.topic: RTYI soundtrack rights and album concept
open_questions.context: Kaze wants to pay the musician(s) for rights and release an RTYI album, potentially packaged as an N64-cartridge-style ROM MP3 player.
questions: Who owns the compositions/arrangements (Badub only, multiple composers, remix rights) and what does ‘buying rights’ mean here?
How would you distribute it legally and technically (Bandcamp, physical cart, ROM-based player, streaming services)?
Is the album meant as a companion piece to the documentary/launch campaign?

open_questions.topic: Unreal Engine project details and team plan
open_questions.context: He proposes a new Unreal demo and a Kickstarter timed with RTYI’s release, while keeping details private for now.
questions: What lessons from RTYI engine development will directly inform the Unreal project (movement feel, camera, level cadence)?
Who from the RTYI team would transition to the Unreal project, and what roles would change?
How do you plan to avoid burnout while running RTYI release logistics and a Kickstarter simultaneously?
